p: In a study in Europe on the association of both temperature and precipitation with violent conflict during the past 1,000 years, Tol & Wagner ( 66) concluded that when temperatures were lower, conflict was more intense. [Notably, they demonstrated that this association was weaker during the industrial era (since 1750).] They concluded that their results do not provide “a clear-cut picture” (p. 77). They predicted that global warming would not likely lead to increased violent conflict in temperate climates ( 66).
